ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was
What is your overall assessment of this course
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learned advanced German grammar, vocabulary, and cultural.

I really improved my use of proper German, and became more fluent in speech, listening, and writing. I finished learning the necessary constructions of German grammar, so that I can now proceed to simply practice for fluency and expand my vocabulary.
As with German 130, my German improved greatly in this course as well. Learned a lot of vocab, structures, and bits about German/European culture.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Weakness: sometimes the work was extensive
Strenghts: Well structured, a lot of feedback, the professor is always willing to help and explain  things, focuses on cultural understanding, develops both speaking and writing

Strengths 
- Truly helps hone speaking and writing skills
- Covers a diverse selection of German-speaking cultures (Eg. Austria, Switzerland)

Weaknesses
- Some of the homework feels more like busy work that actual teaching material
- The course structure becomes somewhat monotonous

It was a bit experimental of course, since it was an unexpected format, but the course really engaged the students nonetheless. Talk Abroad really helped with conversational practice; I began to feel like I was really becoming used to the language rather than just studying it. I also enjoyed that the course taught a bit about the cultures and nuances of German speaking countries, rather than just the language itself. The use of enticing media (i.e Babylon Berlin) as listening and comprehension practice further made the student feel interested and involved beyond just study, which in turn improved listening. The Quia assignments in this course seemed much better than in GMAN 130 as well.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, definitely to anybody interested in learning German. Do take into consideration the time you would need to allocate, though.
Sure, if you want to improve your German speaking and writing skills, or if you want to take higher level German classes.
Yes if you want to improve your German

Yes! It is a great course if one wants to continue after the three required courses to increase fluency. It continues to review difficult areas of the language, while still introducing plenty of new material.
Yes, Frau Sippel is, just like Frau Schenker, an amazing teacher, and I learned a great deal from her.
